title: Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve Injury After Thyroidectomy
setup_script: “On postoperative day 1, you are called to evaluate a 45-year-old female who underwent total thyroidectomy yesterday for multinodular goiter. She is now hoarse and has developed inspiratory stridor. Her calcium level is normal, and her surgical drain has minimal serosanguinous output. How would you proceed?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident assesses airway and examines the patient
dynamic_flow.reply: “The patient appears anxious, with stridor at rest and mild suprasternal retractions. Vital signs: HR 112, BP 135/80, SpO2 92% on room air. What do you want to do next?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident calls for anesthesiology and prepares for airway intervention
dynamic_flow.reply: “Anesthesia arrives and the patient is placed on oxygen via facemask. SpO2 improves to 96%. What is your next step?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident performs or requests bedside laryngoscopy
dynamic_flow.reply: “Flexible laryngoscopy shows bilateral vocal cord immobility with cords in paramedian position. What do you want to do now?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident secures airway with reintubation or tracheostomy
dynamic_flow.reply: “The airway is secured and the patient stabilizes. What additional evaluations should you consider?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident evaluates for compressive hematoma
dynamic_flow.reply: “Neck exam is soft without significant swelling. Ultrasound shows no evidence of hematoma or seroma. What else will you assess?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident reviews calcium and electrolyte status
dynamic_flow.reply: “Serum calcium is 9.2 mg/dL, magnesium normal. What is your next step?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident involves ENT for further evaluation
dynamic_flow.reply: “ENT recommends laryngeal EMG to assess nerve function. How will you counsel the patient and family at this time?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident explains prognosis and recovery
dynamic_flow.reply: “You inform the patient and family that bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury has occurred, that recovery may be possible over 6–12 months, and that speech therapy will be initiated. What additional steps do you take before discharge?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident discusses documentation and disclosure
dynamic_flow.reply: “You document the complication, your discussion with the patient and family, and notify risk management. What is your follow-up plan?”
“You schedule ENT and speech therapy follow-up. At 6 months, the patient has persistent bilateral cord paralysis with significant voice dysfunction. What is your next management option?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident considers medialization or further surgical options
dynamic_flow.reply: “You discuss surgical medialization procedures with ENT. The patient elects to proceed.”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays airway intervention initially
dynamic_flow.reply: “The patient desaturates to 78%, becomes cyanotic, and loses consciousness. CPR is initiated. What is your immediate next action?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident fails to secure airway
dynamic_flow.reply: “The patient cannot be resuscitated. The case ends here.”

critical_decision_points: Immediate recognition and management of airway compromise.
Differentiation between bilateral versus unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury.
Evaluation for compressive hematoma as a reversible cause.
Counseling and involvement of ENT and speech therapy.
Clear documentation and disclosure of complication.

resident_feedback_template: Strengths:You demonstrated strong diagnostic reasoning by recognizing the potential airway emergency. Your communication with the anesthesia and ENT teams was clear and collaborative, and you appropriately disclosed the complication to the patient and family.Areas for Improvement:Consider earlier escalation to airway intervention in cases of stridor to avoid deterioration. Ensure consistent evaluation for reversible causes such as hematoma. Expand counseling to include long-term expectations for recovery and possible interventions.Suggested Reading Topics:- Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve Injury After Thyroidectomy (SCORE)- Airway Emergencies in Postoperative Patients (ACS/ASE Review Manual)- Surgical and Non-Surgical Management of Bilateral Vocal Cord Paralysis
